data.body: In the process of micturition (=urination or voiding) in adults, which role does the somatic nervous system have?

answerChoices.body: It allows for voluntary contraction of the urinary bladder’s wall muscle.
It controls the voluntary contraction of the internal urethral sphincter.
It controls the voluntary contraction of the external urethral sphincter.
None - Urination is only regulated by the autonomic nervous system.

explanation.body:
The process of micturition occurs via the micturition reflex. While this process is mostly mediated by the parasympathetic nervous system, there is some voluntary control via the somatic nervous system. 

There's three primary muscles involved in urination.

$\textbf{1.) Detrusor}$ 
The detrusor is under the control of the autonomic nervous system. Parasympathetic stimulation leads to contraction, which helps expel urine, while sympathetic stimulation does the opposite.

$\textbf{2.) Internal Urethral Sphincter}$
Also a smooth muscle, also under autonomic control. Here the sympathetic nervous system stimulates contraction, which holds urine in. Parasympathetic innervation has the opposite effect. 

$\textbf{3.) External Urethral Sphincter}$
This is a skeletal muscle, under voluntary control by the somatic nervous system.  It's essentially the last line of defense from the release of urine.
